title-group.article-title: Discrete-time adaptive sliding mode controller for vehicle steering systems with preview

article-meta.aff: The University of Tokushima, Ishii, Ishii-cho, Myozai-gun, Tokushima, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Toshio Yoshimura, The University of Tokushima, Ishii 71-17, Ishii-cho, Myozai-gun, Tokushima 779-3233, Japan Email: y-toshio@mxi.netwave.or.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents the design of a vehicle steering system with preview for a vehicle model subject to an uncertain side aerodynamic force by the crosswind disturbance. The steering control with preview is automatically implemented by steering the angles of the front/rear wheels based on the discrete-time adaptive sliding mode controller (SMC). It is assumed that the measurement of the states is taken by the measurement constraint and the contamination with independent random noises. The estimates for the unmeasurable states and the uncertainty characterizing the side aerodynamic force are respectively obtained by the weighted least squares estimator using a set of noisy measurements, and the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC is designed on the basis of the information of the estimates. The simulation result indicates that the proposed vehicle steering system with preview is very effective in the system performance and the practical implementation.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, a considerable amount of research and development for vehicle steering systems has been proposed. The purpose of the steering controls is that the current position of the vehicles tracks the position on the desired course, and the steering controls can be realized by obtaining the steering angles of the front and/or rear wheels. It is seen that the steering motion of the vehicles is generally coupled with the suspension motion, and various research into the integrated controls for vehicles taking coupling into consideration have been developed (Yoshimura and Emoto, 2002, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007). However, it may be assumed that the steering motion is uncoupled with the suspension motion as the road geometry is relatively smooth and straight. The various research and development for vehicle steering systems in the uncoupled situation have been proposed: path control of automatically guided vehicles along the desired course (Freund et al., 1997); steering controller of autonomous vehicles for uncertain systems (Hunt et al., 1996); steering control of autonomous vehicles to perform the manoeuvre automatically or to a certain extent with the driver’s assistance (Lu et al., 2004); driver-aided system for lateral vehicle control (Lauffenburger et al., 2003); nonlinear proportional-integral (PI) front/rear steering control in four-wheel vehicles (Marino et al., 2007); observer-based sliding mode controller in a split-μ manoeuvre (Hebden et al., 2004); tracking for vehicles and estimation of the road geometry (Eidehall et al., 2007); preview steering control for four-wheel vehicles to track the desired course (Lee, 1992; Sharp et al., 2000; Cole et al., 2006); and steering control for autonomous vehicles subject to a crosswind disturbance (Boada et al., 2005; Zhengqi et al., 2003).

The purpose of this paper is to address a vehicle steering system with preview for vehicle models subject to an uncertain side aerodynamic force by the crosswind disturbance based on the discrete-time adaptive SMC. The steering motion is generally assumed to be uncoupled with the suspension motion as the road geometry is assumed relatively smooth and nearly straight. It is a well-known fact that the SMC is an effective approach to design robust controllers for dynamic systems with uncertainties found in unmodeled dynamics and external disturbances (Edwards and Spurgeon, 1998). The main feature of the SMC methodology is based on the concept that the dynamic systems remain insensitive to matched uncertainties and complete information of the states for the dynamic systems are available (Edwards and Spurgeon, 1998; Utkin et al., 1999). Most parts of the SMC methodologies have been concerned with continuous systems, and the number of reports for the SMC in discrete-time systems is increasing because the use of computers and controllers in implementation of control algorithms has recently been increasing. Some research into the adaptive SMC for the discrete-time systems with uncertainties has been presented with estimators to take the estimates for the uncertainties: a discrete-time adaptive SMC for a class of linear minimum phase systems with the colored noise (Chan, 1997); robust adaptive SMC for discrete-time single-input single-output systems, and multi-input multi-output systems with parameter estimators (Chen et al., 2001; Chen, 2006). However, in realistic situations, the dynamic systems are frequently affected by mismatched uncertainties, and the measurement of the states for the dynamic systems is taken by the measurement restriction and contamination with random noises. In the research into the adaptive SMC for discrete-time systems with mismatched uncertainties (Yoshimura, 2008, 2010), estimators to take the estimates for unmeasurable states and uncertainties, and controllers to generate the control signals, have been constructed. The application of the discrete-time adaptive SMC to the design of the vehicle steering system with preview is effective in reality to improve the system performance, but there have been few reports about discrete-time adaptive SMC until now. Therefore, this paper presents the design of the vehicle steering system with preview for the vehicle models subject to an uncertain side aerodynamic force by crosswind disturbance, and the steering control with preview is automatically implemented by steering the angles of the front/rear wheels based on the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC.

The organization of this paper is given as follows. In Section 2 the vehicle is assumed to move at a constant velocity along a road whose geometry is relatively smooth and nearly straight, and is subject to uncertain side aerodynamic force by crosswind disturbance. Equations of motion for the vehicle are described by taking the assumption that the steering angles, the sideslip angle and the yaw angle are respectively relatively small. In Section 3, the continuous state equation with preview is originally developed by using the equations of motion for the vehicle where the uncertain side aerodynamic force is expressed as the product of the nonlinear state function and the unknown parameter. In Section 4, the continuous state equation with preview is transformed into the discrete-time state equation with preview, and the measurement of the states for the vehicle system is discretely taken by the measurement constraint and contamination with independent random noise. Steering control with preview is derived based on the discrete-time adaptive SMC presented by Yoshimura (2008, 2010) where the estimates for the unmeasurable states and the uncertainty characterizing the side aerodynamic force are taken by using the weighted least squares estimator (WLSE). In Section 5, it is proved that the deviation vector is ultimately bounded under the action of the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC if the sliding coefficient matrix is suitably selected and the desired vector satisfies a bounded condition. In Section 6, the practical implementation of the vehicle steering system with preview based on the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC is described. In Section 7, the simulation and the discussion are presented to show the effectiveness of the proposed vehicle steering system with preview for two kinds of road geometries.

sec.title: 2. Vehicle and crosswind models
sec.p:
Consider the vehicle model shown in Figure 1 where the vehicle is assumed to move at a constant velocity V along the road whose geometry is relatively smooth and nearly straight, and is subject to an uncertain side aerodynamic force Fw by the crosswind disturbance. The steering control with preview is realized by the steering angles of the front/rear wheels such that the current position attacks the position on the desired course. Taking the assumption that the higher order terms of the steering angles of the front/rear wheels, δf and δr, the sideslip angle β and the yaw angle ψ are respectively ignored as these are relatively small, the equations of motion for the vehicle model subject to the uncertain side aerodynamic force Fw, where the angles of the left/right wheels are steered in the same directions, can be described as follows (Abe, 1992; Yoshimura and Emoto, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007). (1)mV(β·+ψ·)=Sfl+Sfr+Srl+Srr+Fw
Iψψ··=ℓf(Sfl+Sfr)-ℓr(Srl+Srr)+Mfl+Mfr+Mrl +Mrr-ℓdFw(2) where Sij and Mij respectively denote the cornering force and the aligning torque. It is seen from Figure 1 that the cornering forces are drawn perpendicular to the longitudinal symmetric axis of the vehicle model, not drawn perpendicular to that of the tires. It is derived from the assumption that the steering angles of the left/right wheels and the sideslip angles of the left/right tires are respectively identical (Abe, 1992). Then, Sij and Mij are respectively obtained by using the tire model as follows (Abe, 1992; Yoshimura and Emoto, 2002, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007): (3)Sij=Kijβi
(4)Mij=eiKijβi where βi is the sideslip angle of the tire respectively given as (5a)βf=δf-β-ℓfψ·V
(5b)βr=δr-β+ℓrψ·V Kij is the cornering stiffness expressed as (6)Kij=K1iWij+K2iWij2 and K1i and K2i are respectively the coefficients obtained by the curve fitting to the experimental data, and Wij is the vertical tire load. The vertical tire load Wij is composed of the static load Wijs and the dynamic load Wijd where Wijs is the vertical weight due to the vehicle body and the wheel, and Wijd is the vertical tire force due to the excitation from a road profile (Yoshimura and Emoto, 2002, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007). Since Wijd is relatively small as the road geometry is relatively smooth and nearly straight, Wijd can be ignored compared with Wijs. Therefore, the cornering stiffness Kij given by equation (6) is denoted as time-invariant because Wfj and Wrj are respectively given as (7a)Wfj≈Wfjs=[m2fj+msℓr2(ℓf+ℓr)]g
(7b)Wrj≈Wrjs=[m2rj+msℓf2(ℓf+ℓr)]g
Figure 1.
Vehicle model.

In the crosswind model shown in Figure 2, Ws is the velocity of the crosswind, θW is the angle between Ws and the horizontal line, and ℓd is the distance between CG (center of gravity) of FW and CG of the vehicle model. Then, FW is derived as (Yoshimura and Emoto, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007) (8)FW=Csρ2SA(vs2+ws2) where Cs,ρ and SA respectively denote the aerodynamic coefficient, the air density and the frontal area, and these parameters are assumed constant for the convenience. The vs and ws in equation (8) are respectively the horizontal and vertical velocities with respect to the symmetry of the vehicle model given as (9a)vs=Vcosβ-Wscos(θW-ψ)
(9b)ws=Wssin(θW-ψ)-Vsinβ and CsρSA/2 is an unknown parameter defined as θ. Substituting equations (9a) and (9b) into equation (8), FW is given as (10)FW=Φ(β,ψ)θ where Φ(β,ψ)=V2+Ws2-2VWscos(θW-β-ψ).
Figure 2.
Crosswind model.

sec.title: 3. Vehicle steering model with preview
sec.p:
Consider the predicted course denoted as the slender broken line and the desired course denoted as the solid line in the vehicle model shown in Figure 3. In the figure, the absolute coordinates, (XG,YG) and (XCG,YCG), denote respectively the current and its desired positions, the absolute coordinates, (XP,YP) and (XCP,YCP), denote respectively the predicted its desired positions, and ɛG and ɛP denote respectively the absolute deviations between the current and its desired positions, and the predicted and its desired positions, respectively defined as (11a)ɛG=(XG-XCG)2+(YG-YCG)2
(11b)ɛP=(XP-XCP)2+(YP-YCP)2.
Figure 3.
Predicted and desired course.
Taking into consideration the fact that the road geometry is relatively smooth and nearly straight, β is given as (12)β=Y·GV-ψ

Using equations (1)–(5b), (10) and (12), and defining the state vector xG(t)∈R4 as [ψYGψ·Y·G]T, the state equation is derived as (13)x·G(t)=AGxG(t)+BGu(t)+CGΦ(xG,t)θ where the vector and the matrices are respectively defined as (14)u(t)=[δfδr] AG=[00100001A310A33A34A410A43A44]BG=[0000B31B32B41B42] CG=[00C3C4]A31=1Iψ[(lf+ef)(Kfl+Kfr)-(lr-er)(Krl+Krr)]A33=-1IψV[lf(lf+ef)(Kfl+Kfr) +lr(lr-er)(Krl+Krr)]A34=-1IψV[(lf+ef)(Kfl+Kfr) -(lr-er)(Krl+Krr)]A41=1m(Kfl+Kfr+Krl+Krr)A43=-1mV[lf(Kfl+Kfr)-lr(Krl+Krr)]A44=-1mV(Kfl+Kfr+Krl+Krr)B31=1Iψ(lf+ef)(Kfl+Kfr)B32=-1Iψ(lr-er)(Krl+Krr) B41=1m(Kfl+Kfr)B42=1m(Krl+Krr) C3=-ldIψ C4=1mΦ(xG,t)=Ws2+V2-2WsVcos(θW-Y·GV)

Taking into consideration the fact that the amplitude of β+ψ is relatively small and using equation (12), the relation between YG and YP is obtained as (15)YP=YG+L(β+ψ)=YG+LVY·G where L denotes the preview distance. Substituting equation (15) into equation (14), and defining the state vector xP(t)∈R4 as [ψYGψ·YP]T, the state equation with preview is denoted as (16)x·P(t)=APxP(t)+BPu(t)+CPΦ(xP,t)θ where (17)AP=[00100-VL0VLA31-VLA34A33VLA34LVA41-(VL+A44)LVA43(VL+A44)]BP=[0000B31B32LVB41LVB42] CP=[00C3LVC4]Φ(xP,t)=Ws2+V2-2WsVcos(θW-YP-YGL)
The desired vector xCP(t)∈R4 is defined as [ψC YCG ψ·C YCP]T, and these components are respectively assumed to be bounded within the vehicle’s driving range.

sec.title: 4.1. Design of the discrete-time adaptive SMC
sec.p: Consider the design of the vehicle steering system with preview based on the discrete-time adaptive SMC (Yoshimura, 2008, 2010). The steering control with preview is automatically realized by steering the angles of the front/rear wheels, δf(k) and δr(k), at the sampling instant kΔt where the angles of the front/rear wheels are kept constant over the entire sampling interval Δt between kΔt≤t<(k+1)Δt, and the angles of the left/right wheels are steered in the same directions. Transforming the continuous state equation with preview given as equation (16) into the discrete-time state equation with preview by the difference of first order with the sampling interval Δt yields (18)xP(k+1)=FPxP(k)+GPu(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ where xP(k)=xP(kΔt) u(k)=u(kΔt) FP=I+ApΔtGP=BPΔt Ψ(xP,k)=CPΦ(xP,kΔt)Δt where the pair (FP,GP) is assumed to be controllable. Assume that the measurement of the state vector xP(k) is taken with the sampling interval Δt by the measurement constraint and the contamination with the independent random noise given as (19)y(k)=HxP(k)+v(k) where y(k)∈Rp is the measurement vector (p≤4), v(k)∈Rp is the independent random noise vector, and H∈Rp×4 is the known constant matrix. Moreover, assume that the pair (H,FP) is observable.

Assume a sliding surface to derive the discrete-time adaptive SMC given as (20)σ(k)=SeP(k) where σ(k)∈R2 is the sliding surface vector, eP(k)∈R4 is the deviation vector defined as xP(k)-xCP(k), and S∈R2×4 is the constant sliding coefficient matrix. Assume that the discrete-time adaptive SMC us(k) is composed of two kinds of controls given as (21)us(k)=ue(k)+un(k) where the first and second terms on the right hand of equation (21) respectively correspond to the equivalent and switching controls. Substituting equations (18) and (20) into the time difference Δσ(k+1) defined as σ(k+1)-σ(k), and setting the resultant equation to zero, the equivalent control ue(k) is obtained as (22)ue(k)=-(SGP)-1S[(FP-I)xP(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ -ΔxCP(k+1)] where ΔxCP(k+1) is defined as xCP(k+1)-xCP(k) and SGP∈R2×2 is assumed to be the invertible matrix. The switching control un(k) is assumed to be (Yoshimura, 2008) (23)un(k)=-un(σ,k)(SGP)-1σ(k)‖σ(k)‖ where un(σ,k) is a positive scalar function of σ(k) and ‖ ‖ denotes the Euclidean norm of a vector. Substituting equations (22) and (23) into equation (21), the resultant equation becomes (24)us(k)=-(SGP)-1S[(FP-I)xP(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ -ΔxCP(k+1)]-un(σ,k)(SGP)-1σ(k) ‖σ(k)‖

However, since the switching function included in us(k) has the chattering as the demerit (Yoshimura, 2008), un(σ,k) is replaced by α‖σ(k)‖ where α is taken as a positive constant. Then, equation (24) is obtained as (25)us(k)=-(SGP)-1{S[(FP-I)xP(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ -ΔxCP(k+1)]+ασ(k)}

It is seen that us(k) given by (25) provides slower convergence to the desired course, but it further reduces the chattering, compared with equation (24). However, since the variables xP(k), θ and σ(k) cannot be directly taken from equation (19), these are respectively replaced by their estimates, x∧P(k), θ∧(k) and σ∧(k). Then, us(k) is obtained as (26)us(k)=-(SGP)-1{S[(FA-I)x∧P(k)+Ψ(x∧P,k)θ∧(k) -ΔxCP(k+1)]+ασ∧(k)}

It is seen that the SMC for the discrete-time systems cannot maintain completely the trajectory of the states on because the control signal is generated only at certain sampling instant and is kept constant over the entire sampling interval Δt between kΔt≤t<(k+1)Δt. Therefore, since the trajectory of xP(k) remains in the vicinity of σ(k)=0 as k increases (Yoshimura, 2008), us(k) is called the quasi-SMC. The reaching law for σ(k) is denoted as (27)σT(k+1)σ(k+1)-σT(k)σ(k)<0

Using inequality (27), the equality is derived as follows, (28)σT(k+1)σ(k+1)-σT(k)σ(k)=-γσT(k)σ(k) where γ is a positive factor less than unity. Using equations (18), (20) and (26), the updated equation for σ(k) provides (29)σ(k+1)=(1-α)σ(k)+ασ(k) where (30)ασ(k)=S[(FP-I)x~P(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ~(k)+Ψ~(xP,k)θ∧(k)] +ασ~(k) and the estimation errors in equation (30) are respectively defined as x~P(k)=xP(k)-x∧P(k) θ~(k)=θ-θ∧(k)Ψ~(xP,k)=Ψ(xP,k)-Ψ(x∧P,k) σ~(k)=σ(k)-σ∧(k)

It is seen from equations (29) and (30) that σ(k) is ultimately bounded if α satisfies the inequality given as 0<α<2, and ασ(k) is bounded for any k. Substituting equation (29) into equation (28) provides (31)[σ(k)+ασ(k)-ασ(k)]T[σ(k)+ασ(k)-ασ(k)] =(1-γ)σT(k)σ(k)

Taking into consideration that ασ(k) is equal to zero in equation (31) as k tends to infinite, α=1±1-γ is obtained from equation (31) as σT(k)σ(k) is not always zero. If α=1+1-γ is selected, it is seen from equation (29) that the chattering occurs at us(k) as σ(k) changes the sign in each successive control step, but it improves the convergent ratio as α is taken large in equation (26). While, if α=1-1-γ is selected, us(k) reduces the chattering as σ(k) does not change the sign, but it is not enough to improve the convergent ratio as α is taken small. Therefore, it is concluded from the concept of the chattering reduction and the saving of energy that the selection of α=1-1-γ is better than that of α=1+1-γ.

sec.title: 4.2. Design of a weighted least squares estimator (WLSE)
sec.p:
Design a weighted least squares estimator (WLSE) to take the estimates, x∧P(k) and θ∧(k), for xP(k) and θ. Defining the augmented state vector z(k)∈R5 as [xPT(k) θ]T in equation (18), the resultant state and the measurement equations are respectively given as (32)z(k+1)=fz(z,k)+Gzu(k)
(33)y(k)=Hzz(k)+v(k) where fz(z,k)∈R5 is the nonlinear vector composed of the state function, and Gz∈R5×2 and Hz∈Rp×5 are respectively the constant matrices, respectively defined as fz(z,k)=[FPxP(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θθ]Gz=[GP0T] Hz=[H 0] and 0∈R2 is the null vector. It is seen from equations (32) and (33) that the proposed WLSE is denoted as the nonlinear estimation because fz(z,k) is nonlinear.

Assume the following measure to obtain the proposed WLSE given as (34)Je=∑i=1k[y(i)-Hzz(i)]TW(k,i)[y(i)-Hzz(i)] +[z(0)-z∧(0)]TPz-1(0)[z(0)-z∧(0)] subject to the constraint of equation (32) (Meditch, 1969; Jazwinski, 1970; Yoshimura, 2008) where W(k,i)∈Rp×p is some symmetric positive definite matrix denoting higher weight to more recent information, and Pz(0)∈R5×5 is some positive definite matrix for the initial information. For the simplicity of the derivation for the proposed WLSE, W(k,i) is assumed as exp[-cw(k-i)]Rv-1 where cw is a positive constant denoting the weighting factor to improve the convergent ratio and the stability for the estimation, and Rv∈Rp×p is some positive definite matrix. The proposed WLSE to take the estimate z∧(k) for z(k) is derived by minimizing the measure with respect to z(i) i=0,1,…,k and it is carried out in a recursive form given as (Yoshimura, 2008) (35)z∧(k+1)=z∧(k+1|k)+Kz(k+1)[y(k+1) -Hzz∧(k+1|k)]
(36)z∧(k+1|k)=fz(z∧,k)+Gzus(k)
(37)Kz(k+1)=exp(cw)Pz(k+1|k)HzT[Hzexp(cw) ×Pz(k+1|k)HzT+Rv]-1
(38)Pz(k+1|k)=Fz(z∧,k)Pz(k)FzT(z∧,k)
(39)Pz(k+1)=exp(cw)Pz(k+1|k)-exp(cw)Pz(k+1|k)HzT ×[Hzexp(cw)Pz(k+1|k)HzT +Rv]-1Hzexp(cw)Pz(k+1|k) where Fz(z∧,k)∈R5×5 is defined as the partial derivative of fz(z,k) evaluated at z(k)=z∧(k) and it is assumed to be the invertible matrix. The proof of the convergence of the estimation errors defined as z~(k)=z(k)-z∧(k) has already been presented (Yoshimura, 2008, 2010).

sec.title: 5. Ultimate boundedness of the deviation vector
sec.p: Prove that the trajectory of the deviation vector eP(k) is ultimately bounded under the action of the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC. Substituting equation (26) into the systems given as equation (18) where u(k) is replaced by us(k) yields (40)xP(k+1)=FPxP(k)+GPus(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ=[FP-GP(SGP)-1S(FP-I)]xP(k) +[I-GP(SGP)-1S]Ψ(xP,k)θ +GP(SGP)-1SΔxCP(k+1) -αGP(SGP)-1σ(k)+αP(k) where (41)αP(k)=GP(SGP)-1S[(FP-I)x~P(k)+Ψ(xP,k)θ~(k) +Ψ~(xP,k)θ∧(k)]+αGP(SGP)-1σ~(k)

In equations (40) and (41), partitioning GP into [O GP2T]T where GP2∈R2×2 and O∈R2×2 are respectively the invertible constant and null matrices, and S into [S1 I] where S1∈R2×2 and I∈R2×2 are respectively the constant and unit matrices, GP(SGP)-1S and GP(SGP)-1 in equations (40) and (41) can be respectively expressed as simple forms. Furthermore, partitioning eP(k) into [eP1T(k)eP2T(k)]T where eP1(k)∈R2 and eP2(k)∈R2 are respectively the sub-deviation vectors defined as xP1(k)-xCP1(k) and xP2(k)-xCP2(k), xP1(k)∈R2 and xP2(k)∈R2 are respectively the sub-state vectors, and xCP1(k)∈R2 and xCP2(k)∈R2 are respectively the sub-desired vectors. Expressing σ(k) in equation (20) as (42)σ(k)=S1eP1(k)+eP2(k) and partitioning FP and Ψ(xP,k) into FP=[FP11FP12FP21FP22] Ψ(xP,k)=[0Ψ2(xP,k)] where Ψ2(xP,k)∈R2×1 is the state function matrix, and FPij∈R2×2 i=1,2 j=1,2 are respectively the constant matrices, equation (40) can be partitioned into the two kinds of equations as follows: (43)xP1(k+1)=FP11xP1(k)+FP12xP2(k)
(44)σ(k+1)=(1-α)σ(k) where αP(k) in equation (40) is assumed zero as k is large. Using equations (42) and (43) yields (45)eP1(k+1)=(FP11-FP12S1)eP1(k)+βP(k) where (46)βP(k)=FP12σ(k)+[FP11xCP1(k)+FP12xCP2(k) -xCP1(k+1)]

It is seen from equation (45) that eP1(k+1) is ultimately bounded if the following two conditions are satisfied: (i) the matrix (FP11-FP12S1) is stable and (ii) βP(k) is bounded. Since the pair (FP11,FP12) is controllable, S1 can be obtained such that the eigenvalues of (FP11-FP12S1) lie inside the unit cycle (stable condition). Therefore, it is seen that condition (i) is satisfied. Condition (ii) is satisfied if the first and the second terms on the right hand of equation (46) are respectively bounded. Since the reaching law for σ(k) denoted as inequality (27) is satisfied as 0<β<2 is given, FP12σ(k) remains in the vicinity of zero so that the first term is bounded. Under the assumption that the road geometry is assumed to be relatively smooth and almost straight, the amplitudes of the state variables for xCP1(k) and xCP2(k) are considered to be small and to be bounded on the desired course so that the second term is bounded. Since conditions (i) and (ii) are satisfied based on the above discussion, it is seen eP1(k+1) is ultimately bounded. Therefore, it is concluded that eP(k+1) is ultimately bounded because eP2(k+1) is also ultimately bounded from the relation given as equation (42).

sec.title: 6. Implementation of the vehicle steering system with preview
sec.p:
The implementation of the proposed vehicle steering system with preview is practically performed by using the following procedure (i) and (ii), and the block diagram of the proposed adaptive SMC for the estimation and the control is presented as Figure 4. Figure 4.
Block diagram of the proposed adaptive sliding mode controller (SMC). WLSE: weighted least squares estimator.

(i) Estimation: The estimate z∧(k) defined as [xPT(k) θ∧(k)]T is taken by using equations (35)–(39) where the measurement y(k) given as equation (33) is instantaneously taken by yaw rate sensors and Doppler radars. The WLSE to take the estimates, x∧P(k) and θ∧(k), is instantaneously carried out by using micro-computers so that the time delay to process the data is ignored as it is negligibly small. The information of the obtained estimates, x∧P(k) and θ∧(k), is sent to the controller.

(ii) Control: The proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC us(k) given as equation (26) is derived by using the micro-computers based on the information of x∧P(k) and θ∧(k) obtained from the WLSE and the desired vector xCP(k) obtained from the road geometrical data on the desired course. The control signal is instantaneously generated by the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC, and it is sent to the steering actuator. The steering control with preview is automatically implemented at the sampling instant kΔt by steering the angles of the front/rear wheels, δf(k) and δr(k), using the steering actuator where the angles of the left/right wheels are steered in the same directions.

sec.title: 7. Simulation and discussion
sec.p: The parameters characterizing the vehicle model come from the passenger car produced by Daihatsu Motor Co., Japan (Yoshimura and Emoto, 2002, 2003; Yoshimura and Teramura, 2007), and these are given as m=1030(kg), ms=928 (kg),m2fj=26.5 (kg)j=l,r, m2rj=24.2 (kg)j=l,rIψ=1088 (kg·m2), ℓf=0.968 (m),λr=1.392 (m), λd=0.212 (m)ei=0.03 (m), i=f,r K1i=11.46=f,r,K2i=-5.7×10-4 (1/N)i=f,r and the parameters characterizing the side aerodynamic force FW are respectively assumed as Ws=15 (m/s), θW=-π/2 (rad), ρ=1.2 (kg/m3),SA=2.12 (m2), θ=3.82 (kg/m), Cs=3,V=20 (m/s2)

The measurement is taken by (47)[y1(k)y2(k)]=[1000001000]z(k)+[v1(k)v2(k)] where y1(k) and y2(k) are respectively the measurement, and v1(k) and v2(k) are respectively assumed the zero-mean independent random noise with the variance given as 10-3.

The simulation experiment is carried out where the sampling interval is Δt=0.01 (s), the initial position of the vehicle is (Xo,Yo)=(0,1)(m), and the preview distances are L=5,10,15 (m). The initial condition for the simulation experiment is respectively assumed as xP(0)=[0 1 0 1]T, x∧P(0)=[0 0 0 0]T and θ∧(0)=0. Repeatedly performing the simulation experiment to improve the system performance, the parameter α in the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC is selected as 0.5 (γ=0.75), and the parameters, cw and Rv, in the proposed WLSE are respectively selected as 0.01 and diag[10-310-3].
The road geometries of the desired course are given as follows:
Consider a case where the road geometry is given as quarter-circle and the radius of the circle is given as R. The coordinate (X,Y) of the quarter-circle road is given as (48)X2+(Y-R)2=R2 0≤X≤R 0≤Y≤R
Then, the components of the desired vector xCP(k) are respectably given as ΨC(k)=VRkΔtYCG(k)=R[1-cos(VRkΔt)]Ψ·C(k)=VRYCP(k)=R[1-cos(VRkΔt+LR)]

Since |XG(k)-XCG(k)| and |XP(k)-XCP(k)| are respectively relatively smaller than |YG(k)-YCG(k)| and |YP(k)-YCP(k)|, the deviations, ɛG(k) and ɛP(k), given as (11a) and (11b) are respectively approximately evaluated as (49a)ɛG(k)≈|YG(k)-YCG(k)|
(49b)ɛP(k)≈|YP(k)-YCP(k)| where R is given as 500 (m).

Consider a case where the road geometry is given as sinusoidal. Then, the components of the desired vector are respectively expressed as ψC(k)=YAV[sin(kωΔt)kΔt]YCG(k)=YAsin(kωΔt)ψ·C(k)=YAV[ωcos(kωΔt)kΔt-sin(kωΔt)(kΔt)2]YCP(k)=YAsin[ω(kΔt+LV)] where YA and ω are respectively given as 3 (m) and 2 (rad/s), and the deviations, ɛG(k) and ɛP(k), are respectively evaluated as (49a) and (49b).

The simulation results obtained by the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC are respectively shown in Tables 1 and 2, and Figures 5–18. In Tables 1 (Case 1) and 2 (Case 2), the root mean squares (RMS) values of the time evolutions for the state variables of eP(k) and their estimation errors are obtained where the total sampling number N is given as 500, and the preview distance is given as L=5, 10, 15 (m). Selecting S1 in the matrix (FP11-FP12S1) as S1=diag[20 4.5] for L=5 (m), S1=diag[20 10] for L=10 (m), and S1=diag[20 15.5] for L=15 (m), the eigenvalues of (FP11-FP12S1) are respectively obtained as 0.78 and 0.8 so that eP(k+1) is stable. The tables indicate that the RMS values of ɛG and ɛP more increase as L more increases, but those of (ψ-ψC), (ψ·-ψ·C), (ψ-ψ∧), (YG-Y∧G), (ψ·-·∧ψ), (YP-Y∧P), (θ-θ∧), δf and δr slightly increase or decrease as L increases more. Moreover, the tables show that the RMS value of δf is smaller than that of δr, and the RMS values of (ψ-ψ∧) and (YG-Y∧G) are relatively small. In Figures 5–18, the time evolutions of the yaw angle ψ and its desired value ψC, the current position YG and its desired position YCG, the yaw rate ψ· and its desired value ψ·C, the unknown parameter θ and its estimate θ∧, the discrete-time adaptive SMC us, the equivalent control ue and the switching control un for δf and δr, and the sliding surfaces, σ1 and σ2, are shown where the total sampling number N is given as 500, and the preview distance is given as L=10 (m). Figures 5–8 and 12–15 indicate that the time evolutions of ψ, YG, ψ· and θ∧ respectively approach to ψC, YCG, ψ·C and θ as k increases. However, figures 8 and 15 show that θ∧ almost converges to θ after two seconds, and Tables 1 and 2 indicate that the RMS value of the estimation error becomes much larger than those of the state variables for xP. The time delay in the estimation of θ denotes that θ is not included in the measurement equation, and θ∧ is obtained based on the nonlinear relationship with x∧P given as Ψ(x∧P)θ∧. Figures 9 and 10 show that the amplitudes of us, ue and un become large in the transient state, but become small after the transient state. Figures 16 and 17 show that the time evolutions for us and ue are cyclic, and the amplitude of un is approximately zero after the transient state. Figures 11 and 18 indicate that σ1 and σ2 respectively remain in the vicinity of zero after the transient state. Therefore, it is confirmed from the simulation experiment shown in these tables and figures that the vehicle steering system with preview based on the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC has high performance in control and in estimation. sec.title: 8. Conclusion
sec.p: This paper proposed the design of a vehicle steering system with preview subject to an uncertain side aerodynamic force by crosswind disturbance. The continuous state equation with preview was derived by the equations of motion for the vehicle, and it was transformed into the discrete-time state equation with preview. The steering control with preview was derived based on the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC. The proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC was composed of the equivalent and the switching controls, and was obtained from information about the estimates for the unmeasurable states, the uncertainty characterizing the side aerodynamic force, and the time increment of the desired vector. The proposed WLSE to take the estimates was obtained in a recursive form and was carried out by using a set of the noisy measurements. It was proved that the estimation errors converged to zero as time increased, and the deviation vector was ultimately bounded under the action of the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC. The simulation experiment was carried out for two kinds of road geometries, and the effectiveness of the proposed vehicle steering system with preview was illustrated in the performance of the estimation and the control. The control signal generated by the proposed discrete-time adaptive SMC was sent to the steering actuator, and the proposed vehicle steering system with preview was automatically implemented by steering the angles of the front/rear wheels using the steering actuator. Therefore, the practical implementation of the proposed vehicle steering system with preview was confirmed.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: yaw moment of inertia of vehicle model
distance between axle and CG (center of gravity) of vehicle model
side aerodynamic force by crosswind disturbance
distance between CG of side aerodynamic force and CG of vehicle model
absolute coordinate of current desired position
absolute coordinate of predicted desired position
absolute deviation between current position and its current desired position
absolute deviation between predicted position and its predicted desired position
state vector of state equation with preview and its desired vector
